content.description: Slab to bulge to vertical.  Crux is pulling over the bulge on small crimps.
content.location: To the right of and shares anchors with Poop Deck.

content.description: Climb the first couple bolts of Man The Cannons, then traverse left on the "eyebrows"  and finish on Batten The Hatches.
content.location: Middle of the wall with the "eyebrow" features.

content.description: Interesting features on a slightly overhanging wall.  Make a long deadpoint move to a jug rail, then head left past the crux sloper.  No stopper moves, but not much for rests either.  Good introduction to 5.12.
content.location: To the right of Gnarwhal, and just left of a prominent arete.

content.description: Nice little moderate.  Climb slab for 2 bolts then pull onto steeper but juggy face.  SS glue-in bolts.
content.location: On the slab to your left when approaching the main wall.

content.description:
The Mating Ritual consists of wildly exciting and strenuous movement from bottom to top with very technical sequences on quality rock. The route is visualized in three sections separated by two poor rests. Begin in the chimney and cut left with a big throw past the first bolt. Finagle your way through an undercling sequence (or muscle up directly if you are strong). V7 with the right beta or powerful V8 without. The second crux is the wild flying squirrel move: Launch off a right hand sidepull, catch your left in a wedge, then catch a hidden hold right around the bulge all in one dynamic lunge (V6). Taller/stronger folks might be able to static it. Cop a quick rest on jugs with no feet, then move left into the dihedral for the third, easier crux.

The route is short and stout; shorter but much more challenging than Redwood Burl and similar in difficulty to Thank You Thighmaster but with many more hard moves. The grade was confirmed as “13b or 13c” by Ethan Pringle on the second ascent. It’s a tough one to grade since you can make it super technical or super burly.
content.location: First route on your left as you enter the corridor, just before the log.

content.description: Another short but good route on a slightly under-vertical wall.  Crimps and sidepulls with somewhat poor feet. Crux is probably moving past the first bolt.
content.location: Third route from the left on the Abyss Boulder.  Right side of the wall with the "eyebrow" features.

content.description: Mostly jugs and flat edges up a straight-vertical wall.  Distinct crux face climbing around a wide crack section above the 3rd bolt, with another slightly easier crux to reach the anchors.
content.location: On the north face of the Abyss Boulder, in the corridor.  Directly across from The Slow Spring.

content.description: Long reaches and a highstep on a slightly slabby wall.  Would get more stars if it were longer.
content.location: Third route from the left on the Abyss Boulder.  Look for the wall with the "eyebrow" features.

content.description:
The cave inside the Abyss Boulder has a 45' long roof crack. I spent a while cleaning all the choss out of the crack and had a blast climbing it. Start all the way at the south end and traverse the crack north where the crack varries from body sized, fists, hands, fingers, and even a face hold. Just like Moab's Crack House, touching the ground or the boulder behind you is cheating.

The best logistics are to have a belayer at the base of Gnarwhal and boulder out through the cave. Those newer to doing crack might want a pad and spotter. At the exit of the cave, clip into the third bolt of Gnarwhal and finish it up to the top. If you have large gear, you can have your belayer in the cave and practice invert offwidth technique for your next trip to Vedauwoo by skipping the foot rail in the last 8' of the roof crack and make this thing a 5.13.
content.location: Access the cave by climbing up the first two bolts of Gnarwale or by squeezing through a small hole on the north side of the boulder.
